intro: Agalinis gattingeri, commonly known as the Gatingeri false foxglove, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Orobanchaceae family, which includes many parasitic and hemiparasitic species. The plant typically grows in open, sandy soils and is often found in disturbed habitats such as roadsides and fields. Its flowers are tubular and usually pink or purple, with two lips that attract pollinators like bees and butterflies. The plant is short-lived, often completing its life cycle within a single growing season.
